reviewText:
Extremely disappointing game. Didn't get into the first two red factions, but started at Guerilla and wanted to check out how its sequel was going.... I really wish I hadn't. AI hasn't improved since side-scrolling days, enemies standing upright until you walk around the corner then immediately blast your face off, so no element of sneak or suprise, you eventually get bored of peaking so just run around the corner already firing your gun.

The difficulty is determined by how many enemies there are, not the skill used to take them down (oh look, there is no cover in this room, I wonder how long it will take for the player to die? Let's cram wave after wave of the same ♥♥♥♥ into that room, and to add some origionality" lets make those waves get slightly harder each time.

reviewText:
TL;DR: Overall, it's a farily decent game. You have the Red Faction feel with complete and utter environmental carnage, but the storyline seems out of place.
Quick and Easy game, even on the highest difficulty.
Would overall not recommend.
_______

Dry Humor on a Dry Planet
I will forever love the little bits of comedy that came around during cinematics/gameplay.

Mason: SAM, show me where the bugs are.
-SAM gives locations. Mason sees the hive colony-
Mason: Buckle up, SAM. This may take a while.
SAM: There is no buckle up" directive in my drive.
Mason: -sigh- Just shut up and show me where the bugs are.
SAM: Affirmative.
It's those little chuckles that get you through it all.

However...

The story feels wrong (it was half-decent though).
- First off
date: this feels nothing like a Red Faction game. You fought the Ultor Corporation in the first one
hoursPlayed: and finally the EDF (military/corporation) in the third. This one just suddenly jumps to aliens. What the hell?\nThere were no hints that I recall in the previous 3 games that even remotely stated aliens were here. They just suddenly exist. I suppose you could say those mutants you fought in RF 1 were a hint

rather than something more believable (like Kapek and experimentation on humans/animals they brought (see/play RF 1 for animal/animutant encouters)).
__
The Destruction is awesome
What more can be said? This engine knows how to supply the demand for endless carnage.
Whether you use a Magnet
votesTotal: a Hammer or a Rocket
votesFunny:
just about everything can and will be blown to bits.
It's all so satisfying to see those explosions consume the aliens that won't stay the f**k still.

My only gripe is..

Oh holy ****

reviewText: This is a very solid action game with excellent gameplay, high quality visuals, a large variety of satisfying weapons and destructible environments. Yes, it is linear. No, it is not epically long. If those are big issues for you, then don't get it. Most of the complaints I have read about Armageddon are that it is different from Guerilla. Well, it is. Guerilla is open world, Armageddon is not. Guerilla has lots of driving and combat with vehicles, Armageddon does not. Guerilla also has its share of flaws, and they are different from Armageddon's flaws. In Armageddon, I would have liked more outdoor areas, more human enemies, vehicular enemies, and more large structures to destroy. But despite those shortcomings, it is still a good game.

reviewText:
What a damned waste.

Here's an idea for following up on our brilliantly-chaotic open-world game with a focus on environmental physics-based destruction.  Let's make a generic linear third-person shooter!

What set Red Faction apart was always the interactivity with the world.  Terrain deformation when such things were unheard of in Red Faction 1 and 2, and some amazing building destruction physics in Red Faction Guerilla.  That last one still stands as an amazing open-world game.

This one's Gears of War.  You can still break all kinds of stuff in the world, but since it's ludicrously linear, they have to give you a giant undo gun so you don't strand yourself.  Instead of an open battle for supremacy on the surface of Mars against a paramilitary government, you're shooting spiders in dark caves.

Did the developers even PLAY the previous games?

reviewText:
My hopes for Armageddon weren't high, which is why it’s taken me so long to actually play the game. I was pleasantly surprised though :)

The game is very well made, the environment design, the lighting, the animations and weapon effects. It’s all made to a very high standard, similar to the previous game, Red Faction: Guerrilla. Unlike Guerrilla though, this is a corridor shooter but with some seriously innovative features.

Returning from the previous games is the geo-mod technology that allows the player to destroy the environment. I’m so happy they've brought this back and even enhanced it! The new features include a  magnet gun, which allows objects to be pulled into other objects with great force. This creates a gameplay style I’ve never experienced before! Using a house to crush your enemies never gets old!

The new nano forge ability allows the player to regenerate the environment after you have destroyed it. This I found particularly cool, destroying the environment and then rebuilding to create cover or access new areas. Clearly a lot of thought has been put into new gameplay features for this game.

The story is probably the weakest point here. There are many links to previous Red Faction games (which is always great to see), but the characters are somewhat stale and the story feels as though it’s moving too fast at times. The low res cut scenes don’t help either.

But overall, a very good game. It’s always great to experience new and interesting gameplay mechanics, which Armageddon pulls off very well.

reviewText:
My hopes for Armageddon weren't high, which is why it’s taken me so long to actually play the game. I was pleasantly surprised though :)

The game is very well made, the environment design, the lighting, the animations and weapon effects. It’s all made to a very high standard, similar to the previous game, Red Faction: Guerrilla. Unlike Guerrilla though, this is a corridor shooter but with some seriously innovative features.

Returning from the previous games is the geo-mod technology that allows the player to destroy the environment. I’m so happy they've brought this back and even enhanced it! The new features include a  magnet gun, which allows objects to be pulled into other objects with great force. This creates a gameplay style I’ve never experienced before! Using a house to crush your enemies never gets old!

The new nano forge ability allows the player to regenerate the environment after you have destroyed it. This I found particularly cool, destroying the environment and then rebuilding to create cover or access new areas. Clearly a lot of thought has been put into new gameplay features for this game.

The story is probably the weakest point here. There are many links to previous Red Faction games (which is always great to see), but the characters are somewhat stale and the story feels as though it’s moving too fast at times. The low res cut scenes don’t help either.

But overall, a very good game. It’s always great to experience new and interesting gameplay mechanics, which Armageddon pulls off very well.

reviewText:
This is a short review. I might write a full review sometime later.

Anyway, this game is fun and has full destructible/repairable environments. What's not to like? Sure, it's not open world like Red Faction: Guerilla, and it definetly would be better if it was, but it's still heck of a lot of fun. It took me 16 hours to complete the full campaign, which is longer than your average shooter. This game could also do with a bit of variety. Most of the levels look way too similar and throughout the game I was really hoping for more sections on actual land and not underground. The story isn't perfect and does suffer from some cliches, but it's still good and is better than most of what we get from shooters nowadays.

When I finished the game (which was about 10-20 minutes ago as of writing this review) I felt a bit disappointed and it did feel lackluster. I expected a bit more of an ending. The game doesn't necessarily end in a cliff hanger, but I felt that the ending could have been more conlcusive.

Overall, I enjoyed Guerilla and Armageddon thoroughly and equally (I also remember playing the original Red Faction on the Nokia N-Gage... I know), I honestly really want to see a Red Faction 5. The IP currently belongs to Nordic Games, so Volition, the developers of Red Faction 1-Armageddon (fun fact: also the developers of the Saints Row franchise) will not be working on RF5. Now we can only hope that Nordic Games know what they're doing and will deliver a solid next instalment in the franchise. It would be great if they would try to co-operate with Volition (Volition stated they will not do work on RF anymore, but hey, they could still help). So, good luck, Nordic.

reviewText: The fourth installment of the Red Faction series is going back to the roots - successfully! Armageddon offers an epic linear campaign, underground action, total destruction and even intelligent (re-)construction powered by GeoMod engine 2.5. Your arsenal offers a vast amount of diverse weapons from simple pistols to powerful singularity grenades (plus Mr. Toots^^) and special abilities making you feel like using the Force from Star Wars. The game contains some aweful walkers for even more mayhem. After finishing the singleplayer mode the fun continues with destruction mode (classic!) and all new infestation with two modes: Surival and protection of buildings up to 4 players. If that's still not enough, replay the campaign in plus mode keeping all your progress and weapons right from the beginning. RF4 perfects the experience with fair achievements, forthcoming DLC and a really nice soundtrack from Brian Reitzell. If you like Red Faction, forget Guerilla and give Armageddon a shot!

reviewText:
Underneath this seemingly by-the-numbers corridor shooter, lies an outrageously fun and inventive 3rd person shooter.
A game extremely ahead of its time in terms of destruction and reconstruction, you not only get to destroy everything you see, including entire vertical levels, you often need to reconstruct what you have destroyed (in an astonishingly fascinating way, using the nano forge) in order to continue on.

The graphics start plain, but are increasingly amped up with amazing particle effects and explosions.

AI is impressive and works in team effort utilizing the 3d environment to its fullest.
The enemies are bugs, and this has been done before (lost planet like), but are graphically done well.

Weaponry in the game is some of the most fun I can recall in recent gaming.
The Singularity gun is an incredible and gorgeously animated black hole firing weapon.
The game even has weapon that is a unicorn that fires rainbow particle beams, anally.  Not kidding, its spectacular and it is real.

GPS is well designed and much needed in this maze of level design, albeit very fun and well layed out.

The story is well fleshed out, but takes a lot from Bioshock/Borderlands using Audio Logs.

Overall this is a far meatier game than Red Faction Guerilla (even if it doesnt have a jet pack... hey its got a spaceship!) and a worthy successor to an already great game.

Many people missed this game, probably quitting after the first couple levels, but I assure you, if you salvage, buy weaponry and powerups, you will be waiting for more bugs to pummel with your overpowered weapon rack!

8/10, I would have paid more for this one.

reviewText:
Hey guys, we have the best destructible enviroments made in a game. We also have an interesting setting and driveable vehicles and an open world enviroment and a great multiplayer. Sadly, that was our last game, Red Faction Guerilla. This is not Guerilla. We thought outside the box on this one, and put everything inside a box. That's right, all that destructible envoriment, inside caves where there are barely any buildings to destroy. No more driveable vehicles, apart from one or two mechs. All enemies replaced with aliens which make no sense and are terribly programmed. Multiplayer is also practically dead... But the best part? Oh yes, this game is not even open worlded like Guerilla was.

We took everything good about Guerilla, removed it, and here's your game.

I ♥♥♥♥ing hate you.

reviewText: Red Faction Armageddon is the best part of Red Faction franchise. The game is all about detruction (as one of my friends said: Destruction is good :D) while fighting against aliens and completing objectives. The gamer steers Mason member of military who has the job to stop aliens and save the Mars. Our hero remains alone during the epic fightm but sometimes he gets some help and is allowed to drive very powerful vehicles and robots that makes easier to wipe out tons of alien bugs. Weapons are diverse from light pistol trough plasma cannon to singularity gun, but the most funniest is the magnet gun. As you proceed in the story more and more upgrades are becoming available helping Mason to survive the alien invasion. At the end of the game you will need the upgrades in case you want to survive the Queen. An expansion to the game is Path to War dlc which contains 4 new maps and new weapons and achievements. I recommend them everyone.\nNagyon fain játék, csak a pusztításról szól.

reviewText: I was really hoping that this game would further explore the avenues opened by Red Faction Guerrilla, a game I have come back to over and over just because of the fun and lively open world setting, combined with the absolute joy of destroying stuff. Armageddon still has the wonderful knocking down of buildings, and the magnet gun is incredibly fun to play with, but it just feels like puttering around with little point, compared to the fun of kicking over a UEF hornets nest, trying to desperately knock down a barracks before you are overwhelmed by soldiers or are forced to make a desperate getaway. It was too much of a feeling of being a corridor shooter, after having gotten used to the open and large scale of the previous game. I enjoyed it a little at first, but I quickly got bored and never finished it. Maybe it gets better?

reviewText:
It pains me to say this, but I don't like it... There is a number of core fundamental things wrong with it that I just cant get past.

First off, the game is EASY. I am good at shooters, I'll say that right off the bat. So to compensate that I started it on hard difficulty. And not once have I ever felt like I was in danger, or in trouble, or that I wasn't able to handle what the game is throwing at me even when I am not really putting effort into it at all. And the game relys a lot on atmosphere to make the game, but I feel like I am invinvible. I have only died twice so far. The first was a what What am I supposed to DO?!?" situation. And the other was where I went balls to the wall charge headfirst into something because I thought it would be more fun. And it wasn't really.

Then there is the atmosphere. The game is dead space 2. Just going to say it

reviewText:
Red Faction Armageddon is not fully like Guerrilla, but it's different, and being different is not always a bad thing!

Guerrilla is more of a mission Mad Max type, Armageddon is more like a pure action story line shooter.
If you want more of a mission type, go with Guerrilla, if you want a rich story action Si-Fi shooter, stick with Armageddon. They're both amazing, but deciding which one is better is up to you to decide.

reviewText:
Since its release, THQ and Volition have done everything in their power to try and bring people back to the Red Faction series with very little avail. When you make a game that is a smash success it has to be hard to replicate that success in the form of sequels, which were obviously created, but were a major bust in the eyes of people who actually followed the games since day one including myself.

Volition's fourth attempt in the series is coined Red Faction: Armageddon. Now the subtitle may be a reference to where the story intends to go within the game, but it would also be a good way to describe the game itself. The story begins on Mars in the distant future; just like all others have before it. You play as Darius Mason; a Red Faction member and the grandson of Alec Mason who was the protagonist in Red Faction: Guerrilla in the year 2120. 50 years have passed since the liberation of colonies from the Earth Defense Force. As Darius, you must face off against a new enemy who is trying to destroy stability on the planet and make it uninhabitable to humans. By using terrorist attacks on the Terraformer which provides oxygen and atmosphere to the planet, he is slowly succeeding. The man responsible for all of this is known as Adam Hale. Adam is a cultist leader for the Marauders. This group of mercenaries was converted by him into his own personal army.

After the attack on the Terraformer, you are led to believe that Adam was killed during the explosion which brought the Terraformer crumbling to the ground. Everyone with common sense or awareness of the cliches which are in nearly all movies and games can already tell exactly where this is headed within the first 10 minutes of play. Everyone has been forced underground as a result of these events, which have made the surface of the planet a wasteland. Violent storms, lack of oxygen and mega tornados are what greet people at the surface so obviously a great deal of this game will take place in a linear underground environment. While all the population of Mars is being forced under the surface, a deadly plague strikes which is killing everyone. It is your job to find out what has caused this and who is responsible.

In terms of the story, it is hardly anything riveting or interesting for that fact; and leaves you wondering why you are even playing the game at all. From the beginning, you know exactly where things are going, no suspense, no mystery, just destroy everything and kill everyone until it ends. If you have played the original Red Faction, you will find yourself again questioning this game. What does this really have to do with the first game? Why are people still on Mars if everything has been so terrible three times before? The last but not least; why is everyone trying to either destroy the planet or control it in a totalitarian fashion? Obviously it has worked out so great three previous times why not give it another shot; 4th times a charm right? This series has become a joke. They took something pure and perfect then ruined it by changing the formula until nearly every identifiable shred of the original game no longer existed.

These problems started mainly with Guerrilla, carry over into Armageddon, which added a few more to boot. For the love of god choose a camera and stick to it. The series went from First Person, to a Third Person 360° viewable camera to now a Third Person shoulder locked camera; like I said earlier, formula destroyed. Geo-Mod 2.0-2.5 are again a step in the wrong direction, in the original game you could destroy practically everything, including terrain to make your own paths or find ways around obstacles. This has been severely dialed back, and I am not even sure how it can be dignified with a version 2.0 or 2.5 branding aside from it being the engine name. The only things which can be destroyed are man-made objects, no terrain. While the destruction is impressive, it is all ruined by shooting a wall and not even a scratch showing up.

Hold onto your pants because the bad does not stop there. Where are all the vehicles you could pilot in all previous games? There are vehicles all over this game but none you can drive? Really? It's kind of a slap in the face to be honest, but this comes back to changing the formula. However, they did make a wise decision and reverted back to the roots of the game being linear. The whole Red Faction/Grand Theft Auto open world concept that Guerrilla attempted to do was just too weird and turned a lot of people off; that would explain their logic for Armageddon.

After reading all that is wrong with it let's get to some things which are good and alright. The game looks fantastic in nearly every way, crisp textures, DirectX 11 effects and amazing use of physics on the destruction, the presentation is overall great. With the nice boost in visuals you will also notice some new modes, features and an updated arsenal of weapons. There are two new modes, and they are incorporated very well. The first mode is Ruin. You have a set time to destroy the most structures possible and must obtain a certain score to achieve the next level. There is some replayability to this, but it is stunted by the lack of total levels. The second mode which has been incorporated is Infestation, it is similar to Nazi zombies in CoD and Killing Floor.

You must kill wave after wave of enemies on each level. Some are purely survival and others are defense so you must protect structures from being destroyed. Each level has up to 30 waves to survive. This works out great and is a fun way for friends to play whether it be through the Internet or Lan; there is a lot of replayability here. Conventional multiplayer is something that has been scraped completely, for how this game is I think that was a smart move. If it were still a first-person shooter it would need this to compete with the others; but as it stands it's not something necessary.

The game play is fun in its own right. Very standard Third Person Shooter combat mixed with a Gears of War type cover system. What it does, it does fairly well but the mediocrity of it makes you feel as if you have played this game before. The mix of weapons keeps things pretty interesting. You have a choice of about 10 weapons ranging from just your standard shotgun all the way up to a singularity cannon which creates black holes and engulfs nearby structures. Using the varied weapons can be fun and finding new ways to kill or destroy with them is mainly what the game is about.

Probably the biggest highlight to the entire game is the Path to War DLC. This takes place hours before the events which bring down the Terraformer. The great thing about this is it allows you to actually use the vehicles and play as both sides. It definitely gives a fresh perspective to the game. I would recommend playing this before starting the campaign. With about 45 minutes of game play this makes for an overall nice addition to the game, but I don't think it is exactly worth the money.

All in all, Red Faction: Armageddon is not a terrible game on its own. I hope that is not something I conveyed here. It is a terrible game in terms of it living up to the original which can be said about Red Faction 2 & Guerrilla also, but for what they all do, comparisons aside, they are interesting gaming experiences on their own. If you are looking for a game with deep story, gameplay which is enthralling from beginning to end or something that you will have fond memories of as you get older; this game is not for you. If you want a game which is fun to jump into and blow things up periodically for 20 to 30 minutes at a time without paying attention to what is really going on; this is absolutely for you. Consider it a destruction simulator with a cliched and somewhat boring story to go with it, and you will have the time of your life.

reviewText:
If you liked the original Red Faction titles because of their open worlds, faction system, and replayability; skip this at all costs!!

RF:Armageddon is merely an on-rails console port that has nothing in common with the original games in the franchise except detailed destruction, a few of the original weapons, and the Red Faction name.

The story is very uninteresting, and the dialog is just horrid. Everything smells of console trash; from the magic floating arrows over anything of interest, to the designated checkpoints, to the on-rails approach of each mission (i.e. cunscene after cutscene).

There are NO factions - 99% of the game is fighting aliens, not the EDF or any other factions. There is no free-roam; with very small corridors and caves that have the all too familliar checkpoint system that makes you reload over and over and over until you finish it.

In the spirit of the earlier RF titles, I can't recommend this game at all, unless you just want another mediocre console shoot-em-up.

5/10

reviewText: fun game

Red Faction: Bug Hunt is more in line with the original games than Guerilla was.  It's a linear story-focused experience that I found much more enjoyable than Guerilla.  It doesn't suffer from any of the drawbacks of that bland open world and has a much larger variety of gameplay experiences.

The game has a wide variety of weapons, and they're all far more useful than anything in Guerilla.  The addition of the magnet gun is also fantastic, giving you another way to tear down buildings rather than burning through precious explosive ammo or slowly chipping away with a hammer.  There's even a gun that collects nearby debris and shoots it towards your enemies (in the DLC.)  This time around, only certain objects drop scrap when destroyed, but the upgrade systyem is much more robust allowing you to acquire and upgrade special nanoforge powers along with general upgrades.

The destruction system is great fun like always, and feels improved since Guerilla, with buildings more realistically falling down when supports are destroyed rather than hanging in the air supported by one lone pillar.  In addition, you also have the ability to reconstruct destroyed objects.  Some people think this cheapens the destruction but I find it gives the level designers more options so they don't have to worry about whether you'll be able to continue after a structure is destroyed and also gives you more tactical options, being able to construct cover during combat.

The graphics are quite good, and the game even has full DX11 support.  It even manages to run well even when buildings are exploding all around you.  Unfortunately the game uses an extremely low FOV, though it can be fixed by editing some game files as with all Volition games.

The multiplayer is pretty fun, though I doubt you'll find anyone playing public games so it's best to bring friends.  There is a set of 8 survival maps, where you fight of waves of enemies to either survive, or defend key structures.  It shares upgrades with the single player so you'll have an easier time if you play the single player first.

Overall a fantastic game and I hope Volition keeps working on Red Faction at their new home with Deep Silver.

Alright, first off you don't play this game with an assault rifle or a shotgun. You take your magnet gun, sticky bomb launcher, missile launcher and portable black hole creator. Why? Because you can pretty much wreck everything.

The magnet gun works like this, you pick an object and shoot the magnet at it. After that you pick another object and attach another magnet, which sends object one flying towards object two. You can drop a ton of rubble on an enemy for instance, send him flying into a ravine or make him collide with one of his friends.

You also have a nice wristband with special powers, it can repair pretty much anything you've blown up, create anti gravity fields, create force fields and more.

The story is not worth noting, the characters aren't either and the dialogue is just alright. At around 50% the game picks up some slack. However you spend 90% of the relatively short campaign (6-7 hours) in underground caves and tunnels. This is not exciting at all, in fact if they had not used different colored lighting it would all look exactly the same. You get to go on the surface a couple of times but before you know it you are stuck underground again.

There are just a few different enemy types, most of them jump from wall to wall or vanish and appear again. You wait for them to sit still and then splatter their insides around the cave. Kind of like chasing a mosquito around your room that's keeping you up at night, you wait for it to sit still and -splat-. Your enemies are nothing more than just a pest.

They put some of the coolest weapons on vehicles that you only get to use once in the game, should've made some portable versions of them.
This game just screams for some more creative weapons, and by creative I don't mean a unicorn that shoots rainbow rays from it's behind. Yes they actually put that in the game after you've finished it. I'm talking weapons á la Ratchet and Clank or Resistance.

If you can get this game for approx. 20 cents I'd say do it.

While the ability to wreck the scenery is reasonably entertaining for a while, the missions are very, very linear and the weaponry appears to differ only by visual effect. None of the guns seem to do a lot relative to hurling chunks of scenery around with the magnet gun (lifted from Half Life) so they're rarely used. The combination of repetitive gameplay (walk round a corner, horde of bugs spawn from empty space, slaughter them) and uninspiring, underpowered enemies makes the act of thinning their apparently limitless numbers a bit of a dull distraction from the scenery-chewing. A bit unfortunate in a shooter. It's quite pretty and knocking buildings over is fun for half an hour, but after that I wouldn't bother.
Amazing!! Cant stop playing after you start, keeps bringing you back.

reviewText:
Red Faction Armageddon looks great in DX11, and I had little to no performance issues whatsoever. I did however have audio problems (had to switch to stereo over surround) and occasionally at cutscenes the game would crash. Other than that this game is great. One downfall of this game is that it relies too heavily on drowning the player in aliens, making it near impossible to shoot everything. Luckily when playing on normal mode you're nearly indestructable, so the hordes you face aren't so daunting.

This game has just the right amount of upgrades and the menus are simple and straightforward. When you beat the game you also unlock one of the most badass weapons possible, Mr. Toots.

Overall I'd give this game an 8/10, the only bad part was the immense audio problems - maybe its not really worth 50$ though, so wait for a sale ;)

The 4th in the Red Faction series, Armageddon seems to fall very short from what was just established a game before it. most of the terrain is destructable as you have come to expect from this series, but after a few chapters in the game even that becomes less than entertaining. Armageddon uses an over-the-shoulder view like it's predecessor, but takes away much of the reason to break things as salvage does not exist and you might be lucky to find some ammo for the guns that actually do damage to enemies in the rubble. While recreating broken items with your nanos is enjoyable, the level designs are regurgitated over and over and the enemy AI seems a bit off at times.\n\nThis game features extra modes and difficulties to try and squeeze more interest from gamers, but over all other than fairly decent graphics and the ability to break everything in sight with a magnet gun or a rainbow farting pony, there isn't much to this game of monotomy. Worth a play if you are a fan, but not if this if your first romp on Mars.

I've just finished playing this and wow. I bought this as a retail boxset of THQ games and this game is just fantastic. I haven't played any other Red Faction games, so I can't say how it fits with the story. But as an independent story its pretty neat - nothing too out of the ordinary however.

The graphics are great, although you may become overwhelmed with particle effects at some of the more intense sections of the game. The voice acting and script are both convincing and help add a layer of immersion.

The game handles fantastic - for those who played Saints Row The Third then RFA has exactly the same gun combat.

There is a good variety of weapons including my favourite the magnet gun which allows you to kill the enemies using parts of the landscape. The repair tool that they give you also makes for an interesting gameplay mechanic requiring you to fix items in real time (difficult if you are faced with a few dozen enemies). You also get a selection of vehicles to use - which mixes things up.

The only issues I have with this game is that it is quite short. It has the tendency to randomly quit the game for no reason. Enemies can spawn a few feet in front of you (not cool).

Red Faction Armageddon is a game you may find yourself loving and hating both.  I like Volution games, ( have purchased all but Saints Row 1 , no pc port of it.  )  This is not my favorite but if you can catch it on sale and  have patience you  should have a lot of fun.  It is a challenge to finish it.  I did have the game crash on me about 7 times up to about half way through the game. Requiring a restart of the game, but after about mid game that stopped , no more crashes.  Catch it on sale is always good advice but I myself would wait for sale.

This game was so much fun. A lot of action, a lot of shooting, a lot of blowing things up, and some reparing :P. Vehicle combat was so much fun as well and there was never a dull moment in this game. Unlike the previous one this one was more of a tight corner FPS. Still... The story was awesome and the DLC was also a lot of fun and anyone who likes shooting can really go for this game. 10/10.

Surprisingly fun to play. This last part of the Red Faction series is a really solid third person shooter. Yes it's linear and doesn't have the open world of the previous title but it's closer to the original FPS game from 2001. Be sure to use the unicorn gun :D

reviewText:
Red Faction: Armageddon is a game I have come back to again and again, and I would like to try to explain why...

Almost nothing about Red Faction: Armageddon could be described as 'spectacular'. The plot, for example, is a pretty standard sci-fi 'bug-hunt' affair that sees you battling a plauge of generic nasty aliens and a bunch of crazy religious space cultists, all whilst cracking wise with your AI companion.

Graphically Armageddon looks nice, but is nothing to write home about. The game controls well on a gamepad or a keyboard/mouse and mechanically Armageddon is a very competent game, but doesn't exactly push the games design envelope very far.

But it turns out all of that is fine, becuase the aliens blow up real good when you shoot them, the voice talent is pretty enjoyable and franky you get the impression that Red Faction: Armageddon is trying to be nothing more complex than some good old fashioned alien-blasting fun!

But there is one feature that really stands out, one feature that makes this otherwise average game demand your attention: the destruction engine. You just can't have a Red Faction title without being able to blow literally everything up with a pocket full of high explosives, and believe me when I say that in this area Armageddon really delivers!

As you would expect, almost any man-made structure can be blown apart and you have a generous arsenal of toys with which to do it, ranging from sledge hammers and rocket launchers to high powered lazers and supremely cool 'Magnet-Gun', which will see you launching segments of wall at your foes from across a level and ripping the legs off of guard towers before watching them collapse onto explosive containers and  not-so-innocent bystanders.

Each level presents you with a veritable playground of enviromental destuction. With so many  tools at your disposal you really have the opportunity to get inventive with your violence and use your enviroment against your foes in creative ways. The whole experince is hugely satisfying!

If I had to sum up Red Faction: Armageddon in one word, it would undoubtably be 'fun'. It will never win any awards, it will probably never make it onto anyone's top 10 list, but I guarantee you I'll be re-installing this game in the near future to watch things go boom.

Would I recommend? Absolutely.

Curator-esque Review
More claustrophobic and linear than Red Faction: Guerrilla but still a fun game to play through solo.  Great effects, destruction, and cool tech make the short campaign enjoyable.

Red Faction: Armageddon Review (Spoiler Free)
Story

A mysterious cult destroys the Terraformer, thus destabilizing Mars' atmosphere and driving most inhabitants on the planet underground.  Five years after these events, protagonist Darius finds mining work anyway he can, having left the Red Faction after their failed attempt to retake the Terraformer.  He accepts a contract from a group of shady Marauders and unwittingly releases an entombed alien race.  He is eventually ousted as the the one responsible and forced on the run.  Darius encounters old allies though as he runs and eventually begins the laborius task of driving the aliens back and finding the true identity of those who tricked him.

Gameplay

Armageddon is played in third-person similar to Guerrilla.  The campaign is single player only, but there is also an online co-op horde mode" for up to four players and a sandbox/score attack destruction mode for you to fool around with solo.  Environmental destruction is one of the game's attractions.  At the start of the game
date: you are given a special tool that allows you to rebuild destroyed structures and objects.  Whereas a broken staircase in another game would prevent you from moving forward
recommended: in Armageddon you can literally rebuild the stairs.  Enemies can also make a mess of the environment.  A hulking alien can smash through every wall you put between you and it.  Tentacles will snatch fallen debris and throw it at you.  Destroying buildings is really fun just to watch them crumble.\n\nThere is a a good variety of different weapons to use that destroy the environment in different ways.  Most of the time you will use these weapons to fight various classes of aliens.  Aliens frequently swarm you so your build tool also has some AOE attacks (such as a shield
hoursPlayed: anti-grav
voteText: and force-like push) to create some breathing room.  You will also get to pilot some pretty awesome vehicles.  The story plays out as you would expect it but what you'll be doing in each mission is highly varied.  The campaign never got dull for me and I was excited to play through it again on a harder difficulty.  Co-op is sparsely populated.  Although you can play it alone
helpfulPercent:
it really is not as fun as the campaign.

Design

The aliens in Armageddon look amazing.  Their are multiple varieties of creepy crawlies each with their own color scheme
votesHelpful: behavior
votesTotal: and on-screen effects.  All of them are very well animated.  Sound and lighting are also very nice
votesFunny: giving you the claustrophobic dread of being trapped in the dark underground.  All of the environments look nice too
commentsCount: whether they be vast caves
column16: undeground towns
column17:
or surface camps in the middle of a lightning/sand storm.  Voice acting and cutscenes are great and the cast is alright for what the game is.  Music choice is appropriate though nothings really stood out to me.

Final Thoughts

Red Faction: Armageddon is a fun game to play through on your own a couple of times.  Fun gameplay

I've just finished playing this and wow. I bought this as a retail boxset of THQ games and this game is just fantastic. I haven't played any other Red Faction games, so I can't say how it fits with the story. But as an independent story its pretty neat - nothing too out of the ordinary however.

The graphics are great, although you may become overwhelmed with particle effects at some of the more intense sections of the game. The voice acting and script are both convincing and help add a layer of immersion.

The game handles fantastic - for those who played Saints Row The Third then RFA has exactly the same gun combat.

There is a good variety of weapons including my favourite the magnet gun which allows you to kill the enemies using parts of the landscape. The repair tool that they give you also makes for an interesting gameplay mechanic requiring you to fix items in real time (difficult if you are faced with a few dozen enemies). You also get a selection of vehicles to use - which mixes things up.

The only issues I have with this game is that it is quite short. It has the tendency to randomly quit the game for no reason. Enemies can spawn a few feet in front of you (not cool).
Some very peculiar guns and gadgets make this game worth a try, and with the usual deals it gets on, you may just risk it.

It's a solid 3rd-person shooter.

Everything else about it is a concise encyclopedia of what NOT to do when writing and developing a game. The story is silly and contrived (and aliens in red faction is the worst thing), the writing is just outright bad (but it was written by syfy so what do you really expect), and the characters are all boilerplate and unlikable.

Don't even pay $5 for it. It's not worth any money, really, unless you HAVE to have more Red Faction.

Another heroic tale to the Mason lineage and an all around fun game. A little different than the previous Red Faction due to being less about destruction and more about survival. Instead of destroying buildings you're repairing them with the Nano Forge. Armageddon is more a storyline than a sandbox, following the story of Darius Mason as he saves Mars-manity from the awakened alien swarm. Actually, to be honest, it's is entirely story-based with 4 person Coop Invasion and Destruction missions as a bonus.

After one playthrough the fun begins on your 'New Game +' where you unlock two new weapons, an assault rifle that homes in on enemies and Mr. Toots the rainbow farting rainbow unicorn created by YouTube user Freddiew. You are also able to unlock cheats and weapons torn off of vehicles with salvage for even more destruction and killing fun. I personally use the L.E.O. Triple Homing Rocket Launcher.

All in all, a fun addition to the Red Faction series.

I've been a big fan of the Red Faction series since the original Red Faction.  This reboot of the franchise has disappointed me.  I liked the linear game play in Doom.  I expected it there.  In Red Faction it was linear without being linear as you could take different ways to get to different places through the walls.  The last game was also sandboxish.  This rendition reminds me of Doom 3.  Sure you can blow *almost* everything up, but you can't go through the walls unless it is scripted.  I'm about half way through the game and while it has been enjoyable it is no wehre near as fun as the original Red Faction or even Red Fracion Guerrilla.  It's worth the money but do not expect open sandbox with non-linear game play.  Go into this game expected Doom 3 and you will be more than pleasantly pleased.

The main story was very short; it only took around 10 hours, but if I didn't obsessively scour every nook and cranny for upgrades, I probably could have breezed through in 6. What was there was pretty dang fun, particularly the vehicle sections. It never really felt that there was any real danger in these sections, just good old fashioned blowing stuff up.

Which brings me to my next point, it rarely felt like there was any danger in the game at all. The difficulty curve was extremely inconsistant to say the least. Even towards the very end, the vast majority of enemies were more an annoyance than a threat, going down extremely easily. Then, every so often, they'd throw in a couple of enemies that can eat a dozen rockets without dying, and can kill you in one good hit. Usually in cramped spaces. Don't get me wrong, I like a challenge, but spread it out a bit. Make all enemies a viable threat rather than just one.

The story was pretty generic and predictable.

Despite all this, I thoroughly enjoyed the game. Why? Because flawed as the game is it was a lot of fun. Good old fashioned blasting through thousands of enemies in a sci-fi setting. And, of course, the destructible terrain that's a staple of the series. Don't expect a good story, or a massive, epic campaign, but do expect addictive gameplay, interesting weapons and a good way to zone out.

Would I buy this game for retail? No. But if you can get it on sale, I'd highly recommend killing a few hours on it.

Red Faction Armageddon...

Well let's get one thing out straight away, this game follows the original Red Faction (released in 2001) gameplay and not the Red Faction Guerialla, meaning that you will NOT get an open world, you will not get ability to steal cars and you will not get ability to do whatever you want.

So what will you get?
You will get a typical mindless console shooter, with scripted events and destructible environment, only in places where developers want you to be able to destroy it. So for example, you can't go trough the wall or dig a hole.

Story:
Angry cultists wan't to destroy teraformer to free indigenous creatures and control mars. You must stop them.

Gameplay:
Go there, do that, shoot shoot shoot, cliche rocket turret stages, and some boring stages where you control walkers or fly something that looks like VANU SCYTHE from planetside 2, but again there is no open world so you just go from point A to point B watching scripted cutsences and falling for obvious traps, be carefull not to wonder out of the are otherwise that will result in a mission fail... Nothing innovative, apart from ability to destroy buildings and then fix them back and then destroy again, but this gets old real quick. Also there are NPC's but they are immortal, oh boy don't we love that...

Enemies:
Well there are few enemies in this game, lets see 3 different generic tribal guys, maybe 8 unique monsters that you keep killing in duration of whole game and 1 super hive boss monster. Not fun and not challening.

Verdict:
This whole game is just a typical mediocre console shooter for typical console users. It requires 0 intelligence as game is holding your hand on every step and best part is when you complete it, it rewards you with a...pony, thats right a rainbow pony oh and a gun that has auto aim so that it's easy to shoot with a controller.

So this game proudly achieves the death of red faction franchise and a whopping 2/10 for PC and probably 10/10 on a console.

I found this third person shooter a lot of fun. I've never played any of the other Red Factions, and am told that some of them (if not all) had a more open world feel compared to this much more linear adventure. However, I think its average metacritic score of 70 odd suffers from these sorts of comparisons, as it's a pretty enjoyable game in its own right without any previous experience with the rest of the franchise.

There are a decent range of weapons that can float different people's boats, but I settled into my favourite four pretty quickly - the magnet gun, sniper rifle, mace (for up close and personal squishing), & a heavy damage weapon (which was the plasma cannon for a long time, rocket launcher, and then finally the singularity cannon). The best thing about the game however, is how much of the environment is destructable. It can break from enemy attack, your own attack, or you can even use it to harm enemies (particularly with the magnet gun). It's honestly one of the best features of the game, and using your particle repairer, you can build up most of the destroyed environment to destroy or throw at enemies again!

Replayability may be a little sticking point however. Like I mentioned the single player is quite linear though can obviously be replayed. However, there are another two gamemodes, one of which can be multiplayer. The first is ruin which is essentially using all your best skills at destroying as much of the destructible environment in the map you're put on. There's a short time limit and points are earned on how much damage you do and at what efficiency. You essentially need to destroy X amount of points to complete the few different maps they have and can continue to try set bigger scores. However, it feels like just the addon it is rather than a completely different game mode. The second is Infestation, which is essentially defeating waves of enemies which get progressively harder (up to 20 waves per map). You can solo this or play with other people, with some similarities to that game mode in Gears of War. I'm not sure about whether or not you spawn more enemies when you play with other people compared to solo though (as I haven't played multiplayer), but I'd hope so given I was able to handle most things solo with just the magnet gun and a decent position on the map playing it smart. The better of the two additional gamemodes for sure, but only extends replayability a little bit more.

This game is not going to win any prizes, but overall was a good experience, I wont play this game again, but the time that I spent playing this game was fun

This a good shooter game, with nice graphics and physics. The reason why i don't recommend it is the folowing : to me it is not a Red Faction Game nor story.

More an Half-Life-like than a Red Faction Game. The universe is quite the Red Faction one (you're on Mars, underground), but the concept is not the original one. Will have to fight against bugs-like E.T.. About 10 different types of ennemy, weapons are quite new too compared to the first Red Faction. An upgrade system based on the Red Faction : Guerrilla one, with metal to pick up and spend is available, but upgrades are about player and the nanoforge abilities, not about creating new weapons. The Nanoforge is a great change on this Red Faction episode : giving you some powers, such a an impact pulse crushing what is in front of you, a shield, or a shockwave. But the first and most important one is the repair ability : Red Faction has always been know by its physics and its incredibly destructible environment. You can now repair everything. your stuck in the way ? Destroy the path to get out and repair it to continue. No more shelter to protect yourself againt enemy fire ? Rebuild them where they were.

Concluding, it's a really nice TPS, in the spirit of Red Faction, but this is not a Red Faction game.

Not as good as guerilla, but fully destructible environments, you can't not love that. And the game is worth playing twice just because of Mr toots not counting the extra guns perks and abilities you get in a second playthrough

The story is very generic, with generic settings, the only redeeming quality is the destructive enviorment, that is restrictive to say the least, and the gun selection, there are some cool ones.


All in all this game is a modern TPS with a generic plot and characters i could care less about, as a fan of red faction 1 and II i am dissapointed but expected worse to be honest. Its the previous installment but instead of open world its inside dark caves and ghetto/shantytown enviorments.

tl;dr

A generic console port (that crashes all the time) that is only worth buying at 90% off its original cost. Only redeeming factors are the physics, guns, and destruction.

reviewText: A game about blowing ♥♥♥♥ up and aliens and such. I have played way worse that actually expected me to take it seriously. I like blowing ♥♥♥♥ up. I dont give a flying ♥♥♥♥ about alien games.
Genuinely, this isn't a bad game at all. Definitely the most destructable game on the market. The story is excellent, and even if you have a ♥♥♥♥ PC, this game will run no problem.

Red Faction: Armageddon, like its predecessor (Guerrilla), proudly flaunts its massively destructible environment. The player can tear down any building he so wishes and in this new (and perhaps final) iteration of THQ's long running franchise, buildings can now be restored. But is this gimmick enough?

Manipulating buildings isn't the sole gameplay at work here. Armageddon is a third person shooter that plays similarly to any typical third person shooter in the market. Even more generic is its plot that revolves around the uprising of an alien species that threatens human life on Mars.

My biggest grievances though are the removal of Guerrilla's open world. As a consequence, Armageddon is a very linear affair. That's not to say it isn't a blast, but more freedom might have made the game much more engaging.

Armageddon isn't Game of the Year" material
date: but I'd be lying if I said it wasn't fun. Just demolishing buildings in this game may be worth the admission price.\n\nGrade: B"

reviewText: Despite the fact that I have never played any of the other Red Faction games, I love this title. The story is very captivating and I love the large array of weapons that you can choose from. This game seems to always keep me on my feet, shooting aliens here, one there, it is constantly making me energetic. I have only put 2 hours into the game and I have only reached 20% of the entire story mode, which means that there is a fairly long story. Even after I get done with the single player campaign, there is 2 OTHER multi-player modes that I can play. The graphics look very crisp and nice. I like how (most) the world is fully destructable, using my Maul I can tear down walls or any various obsticles that stand in my way. I will probably find myself playing this game when I complete it again because this is a very nice title. I am concidering playing the other Red Faction games because people have said that this was the game that ruined the entire series. I don't know what made this game so much worse for the Red Faction series. I like to play shooters and adventure titles, this was a very nice game for me to pick up, it is a 3rd person action adventure shooter title that takes place in the future years. I am not extremely far in the story yet so I don't exactly have a really good standpoint as to what's going on in the game's storyline. I would reccomend this to someone who hasn't played any other Red Faction titles because it seems to me that Red Faction players seem to hate this game. The game really doesn't seem that repetative to me, but sometimes it can be. It's not as bad as Dead Island but it can get that way sometimes. I don't die normally, I have only died once and that was on accident. I have the difficutly at Normal setting so if it were me, I'd set it to hard or something above Normal for someone looking for a little harder AI to fight against. I'd give this game a rough 8.9/10 it's a great title if you want a 3rd person shooter kind of like Gears of War.
I would not recommend this game. As far as cover based shooters go it is clunky and not really all that fun.\nEven it's main selling point is really just a gimmick.
The destruction engine is the saving grace of this game. But it is limited.

Red Faction: Armageddon is shorter than Red Faction: Guerrilla. I clocked at 8,5 hours. Not counting the extra gamemodes and getting all achievements, plus playing the multiplayer which I will not cover.

Red Faction: Armageddon is a linear third person shooter, with the destruction mechanics of the previous title Guerrilla.
You play as a member of the famous Mason family, getting into trouble. This trouble is a new kind of alien life form hidden in the planet Mars. You will use different futuristic weapons of personal destruction to get things done.

From melee to rocket launchers, from ground to air vehicles, all is a fun way to do what Masons do best.

|Good stuff:
-Well optimised.
-The graphics are beautiful. Environments are well designed to fit the mood of that current level.
-Geo-mod is back in good shape with better optimised performance when there is allot of detailed destruction around.
-Main character has more personality than his ancestor Alex Mason in the previous game.
-Support character for Mason (also seems to grow with the main character).
-Repair the environment when you need it, or use it against enemies (to make cover etc).
-Collectibles.
-Level variation (big and small levels).
-Enemy variation.
-Weapon variation.
-Upgrade system.
-Decent length singleplayer.

|Not really:
-Story seems to have plot holes.
-Could Bastion not have been a hub to get upgrades etc?
-That's really it from what I can remember.

|Rating:
8 of 10 should be good (for singleplayer only).
Thanks for reading. Hope it will help you get to an idea about the game from my perspective.
At first I was sceptic about the whole game not being open world, because I played every title in the Red Faction series.
Where the first is my favorite (PS2 at the time), than Guerrilla and Red Faction 2 the worst.
Playing through Red Faction Armageddon removed any negative thoughts before playing the game and had allot of fun.
That's it for now.

The game itself is decent, but taking free-roam out of the equation has ruined the fun in this game almost completely. The best thing about Guerilla (apart from the destruction itself), was the freedom that I can run around in an open world and destroy whatever I like. This has been taken out of the game, and it really feels empty now. Besides, the story isn't even that great, and I'm sick of shooting bugs off of a wall.

Well, do you remember the beauty of destruction? Blow of wind in your face while dashing around rocks of Mars, the feeling of freedom and choice, as to where you go and what you blow up? The series of interesting and fun to play challenges?

Well this game has none of it.

It had potential to be a marvelous continuation of an awesome game, but instead, it got callofdutyfied. The game is linear, plot is boring, the main character even more so.
The only fun part of the game IMO is the magnet gun. That's it.

Would not buy again.
was pretty dam fan. 7/10

This was an alright game, nothing really that spectacular.  The gameplay is linear once again, breaking away from the open world of Guerrilla.  The destruction element is still there, but less so than any other Red Faction game I remember. You still get to tear down buildings, but now it seems that many of them are mission objectives that are placed intentionally. The weapons are fairly creative and fun to use, I really liked the gravity gun.  Storywise, I didn't feel like it tied into any of the other releases in the franchise, like they could have easily taken all the Red Faction names and characters out of the game and it wouldn't have changed things at all.   Amusing for a playthrough, but not really memorable.\n\n5/10

Armagedon actully feels more like an actual Red Faction game then Guerrilla since it's linear and majority of the game is underground (just like in Red Faction 1) but Guerrilla is much more fun and of course longer, Armagedon is only 6 hours long and because of it's linear design it lack alot of the fun aspects from Guerrilla.The game also has survival co-op mode ,it's  pretty good but sadly i wasn't able to enjoy it much since almost no one has the game on my friends list. The design of Armagedon  feels very old school, not many cutscenes and the levels actully give you a bit freedom to explore areas  unlike in most games nowaday, it also features a great variaty of weapons, from guns that shoot mini black holes to giant laser rifles which can burn an entire building down. All in all, it's a fun game but just to short and because of that it's only worth picking up if it drops to 5 Euros or lower.

reviewText:
Give a man a massive enviroment filled with beauty and he will admire it. Give him an arsenal of weapons with creative ways and he will destroy it. This utilizes the concept of if it isn't nailed into the floor it can be obliterated, though if it is nailed down you can magnitize it out and then destroy it.

This is the first ever RF game I played and I totally enjoyed every second of it. It has a intelligent way of knowing when too much is enough; throwing you into new enviroments with new obstacles before you have a chance of getting bored.

It does lack the major politcal undertone that the series is supposedly known for, unless I missed it, aswell as the Free Roaming objectives that I was told was present in the predecessors.

It reminded me a lot fo Jak and Daxter which made the gameplay more enjoyable, though at times it seemed like a drag between point A and B with constant repeative objectives instead of plot.

The creativeness of the weapons and power you have makes this game worth whatever the asking price is.

I'm totally amazed with this game. I mean, this is seriously one of the best games i have played in 2011.
I loved the new direction they took with this game, it's more linear but the storyline is much more detailed and interesting.
Something i really liked about this game is the weapon arsenal, it's simply fantastic. Especially the magnet gun and the black hole gun. The level of destruction is huge and spectacular.
You also have a free mode with no time limit where you can destroy stuff and rebuild it again.
Infestation mode, team up with 1, 2 or 3 friends in a battle against bugs and other creepy crawlies where you have to protect structures from damage, or survival mode.

This game is so well made that it allows you to change a lot of graphical settings. Port or not, it runs so perfect and smooth without a single problem.
I'm running it fully maxed out + DX10/11 and god, it looks beautiful!!
Another contender for game of the Year 2011..
Thanks for such amazing game.

Well, as a game, RF:A is quite enjoyable. It is fun and like all RF games, RF:A continues with great and innovative weapons.

Sadly, me and countless other RF fans expected this sequel to be more akin to RF: Guerilla, where the game is an open-ended sandbox game similar to a GTA style. This RF:A is more like a corridor action game fused with scripted gameplay.

The story is very average-ish and could've been better. Even if he game feels rushed, it gave me a few hours before reading the credits. My biggest disappointment is while RF:A wasn't a poor game yet not a kickass one, I'm very saddened that this game is the last of the RF franchise.

Maybe Volition will get permission to reboot the franchise someday? I hope so and while at it, how about making a true sequel to Guerilla, in an open-ended gameplay?

Overall, I'd give this game 7/10. I got it on a steam deal, do the same!

PS: The DLC Path to War" is decent. It provides you  2 extra hours of gameplay."

You won't find this in any review but I very much thought this game was the peak of the series. It took them 4 games to create the engaging, visceral, destructive experience they were going for here and with the culmination of all of the lessons they have learnt, Violition has managed to create the most empowering third person shooter ever. Stasis in this game makes Isaac Clarke look like a noob, it not just stops enemies but drains their health and replenishes yours. The Mechs from F.E.A.R. were awesome? Nope, they cant quite charge through a wall, crush all the enemies in the way and cause the building they just went through to collapse. What's a gravity gun again? The Magnet gun is my favourite gun ever (along side the Portal Gun). This is the power-fantasy any crazy like me has been waiting for. Sniper shooting at you? Shoot a magnet at the base and another at the roof. The base flies upwards into the roof and the whole thing implodes and then collapses. Survive that! Boss fights consist of throwing the boss around the enviroment or pieces of the environment at them until they are impaled by debris and their body parts scatter with a gratifying splat. The campaign does get tedious towards the end though, with one long mission underground with no destructible environments and the story takes itself more seriously than I can. But Horde mode and a free form destroy everything 'Ruin Mode' provides some online fun. Valve better start working on Half Life 3 or everyone is just gonna rip off the old games and forget about them. R.I.P. Gravity Gun.

Like every Red Faction sequel, Armageddon takes everything that was amazing and wonderful about the game that came before, and almost completely trashes it at best, or simply drops it at worst. Armageddon harks back to the original Red Faction and Red Faction 2's linear shooter stories, while trying to play up its roots in Guerilla's lovely open world. Lots of things to destroy, and lots of fun ways to do it, but Armageddon feels like the Walker that crushed the oppresive-regime-trope camel's back.

After playing this game, I have played all the RF games, and I can now tell you which one is the worst. It's NOT Red Faction: Armageddon. The worst RF game goes to Red Faction II. Seriously, Armageddon is better than I thought it would be. The story is ok somewhat, but it's better than in RF:G. You play as Darius Mason, grandson of Alec Mason from RF:G, and he has more personality than his grandfather. He can be hilarious at times, especially when interacting with his S.A.M. (Situational Awareness Module) A.I. The theme of revolution is still here, although not as it was in previous games, you'll see what I mean. The campaign last for roughly 15 hours. (My playtime shows less because I wasn't connected to Steam most of the time).

As for gameplay, it's really fun. Geo-Mod is still here. My main gripe is the removal of open-world. That's really a step back. It could easily have been implemented here. An underground open-world? That would have been great. But I like the new weapons such as the Magnet Gun. It allows you to latch magnets between two objects making one move towards the other. Upgrades are nice too. Taking out the baddies is really fun. What I really didn't like is how the game holds your hand. Not only do you have an objective marker, but also an arrowed path telling you where to go, leaving no room to find where to go on your own. And during boss fights, there is an icon telling you where you shoot, such as weak spots. Too-much hand-holding! As for Infestation mode, I haven't really played it yet, but it's a Horde mode, where you fight endless waves of enemies. Sound fun.

In the end, RF:A isn't bad, but it could have been better. Back when it was released, it would be worth a rental, but buying it now wouldn't be a bad idea, since it's relatively cheap nowadays. Now, Nordic games has control of the franchise, and they have promised a new game. Well, let us see how that turns out...

Things blow up really prettily. You can put most of it back together too, so you don't have to worry about blowing the wrong stuff up.\nAside from that, it really has nothing to recommend itself. The story is a thin paste that's equal parts Aliens and Total Recall, with gristly bits of that B movie that was playing at 2 AM last Saturday. Gameplay is repetitive and the vaunted scenery wrecking gimmick wears thin quickly.\nRed Faction: Armageddon goes straight back to its shooter roots-- that is to say, linear paths with occasional and short forays off to little caches of gear, with the occasional switch to throw or object to explode to... well, I suppose it was meant to reduce the monotony, but it really didn't work very well.

To start, I greatly enjoyed the previous game Guerilla playing it twice through.

Going into this game I expected a similiar fun experience with being able to demolish entire cities. That was my mistake. While I found this game extremely fun in itself, any fan or person thinking this is like the old ones, just hold the phone there and read what I have to say.

Red Faction: Armageddon takes place almost entirely undergound, and unlike the very first Red Faction game, you cannot destroy the tunnel walls. This dispenses an atomosphere of restriction and lack of freedom, which compared to its' predecessors this game is restrictive. There are only a couple city-like places in the begginning that you can demolish and from there, you go undergound where there are just some structures you are allowed to destroy. Any old fan will be dissapointed. On top of that, the developers brought in a whole new aspect of aliens that you are fighting to save your existence. Personally, this doesn't bother me, but others may find this a turn off.

Having said that, looking at this game as if it was its own series, it would be very fun. The destruction/rebuilding engine is still awesome in the limited amount you can use it, and it is just as fun as ever to clear your enemies using with the environment, like caving the roof of a shack in on a horde of aliens charging you. The upgrade system for your weapons and abilities was definitely one of my favorite parts. I felt the upgrades were noticable, which made me feel accomplished when I could afford them. They greatly change gamplay, making each players fighting style a bit different depending on how they go about upgrading.

To wrap this up short and sweet:
--Pros--
The game is fun, featuring a moderately decent story. The mayham and methods of killing are where this game shines, allowing you to use your environment in fun and destructive ways, then rebuilding it (with the nano forge) and starting all over for the next wave of enemies, who you are already devising cunning new ways to splatter and break
--cons --
I would not even bother comparing this to the old series, and many fans will be dissapointed if they buy this.

IMPORTANT: This game does not allow for the free-roam that guerilla did, this was where most of my dissapoinment stems from.

reviewText:
I picked up the Red Faction Complete bundle over the holiday sale after asking a few friends and getting more information on the game. Before I started playing RF4, I played through Red Faction Guerilla from start to finish.
The beginning of RF4 started out setting the story to (hopefully) be fighting an extremeist branch of the Marauders but as soon as the 2nd mission start everything went to ♥♥♥♥.
The story mades less sense and seriously... since when is Red Faction a Destory all Aliens" shooter?! This is not DOOM!
Save your money.
Do not buy Red Faction Armageddon!"

Going to keep this one simple. This is, and always has been my favourite game on the Xbox, and now it's on Steam I've fallen for it again! Once you complete the amazingly fun and action packed story, not only is there additional DLC, but this games campaign has such awesome replayability that you don't get bored!
Also, the multiplayer (1-4) is just as much fun and has kept me entertained for hours on the console! Play with up to 3 of your friends in 'Infestation' and either play survival (waves of fun) or defend areas from attack. There is also a game mode called 'Ruin' where you can literally just take your time destroying the environment, or cause as much destruction as possible within one minute. Also, you can transfer abilities from the story over to the multiplayer!

The amount of weaponry and gear at your disposal is awesome, and the fact that you can not only interact (destroy) your environment, but you can then repair the environment too with the Nano Forge and the help of S.A.M (your Situational Awareness Module). Another point to raise is the fact that the Nano Forge, weaponry and armour are all upgradeable which means there is no linear path to follow, however you can choose which path to take.

If i was EVER to give a game 10/10, this is it.

reviewText: Red Faction: Armageddon is a pretty good game but sadly not recommended. With an uninteresting story line and a typical third person shooter, there's pretty much nothing else do in the game. Sure you can upgrade your weapons and your super awesome wristband fixer ♥♥♥♥ and also you can break stuff around you with Volition's awesome Geo Mod 2.5 physics engine and see things break and explode to pieces and then fixing it all up, but other then that the characters are just not interesting enough to even care about them. It's just over the top action pack, one man army against an alien hoard to save his people from being eaten and to kill the men who started all this, that's pretty much story. But it has some memorable parts like a Red Faction 1 references like there's this one time the main character will talk about some Martian Revolution or the Miner Uprising and Ultor the head of the mining complex and some other ♥♥♥♥ like that, bring back some pretty good memories. But you just can't beat the first Red Faction not even Red Faction Gurilla or Red Faction 2 can beat the first Red Faction but Red Faction 2 ain't all that bad but still can't beat Red Faction 1. I suggest getting it when it's really cheap it's just not worth paying $20 for this  game.

reviewText: It's a horrible game in many ways. The narrative is bad, shooting mechanics are barebones and it's extremely linear. The game has a button that shows you the exact path you need to take to proceed, and at one point even the game itself makes a self-referential joke about its linearity.\nObviously no actual effort or creativity went into making it, so you should go in with the same attitude. It's a stupid B-movie esque rollercoaster ride that lasts for 8 hours. If you can accept it for what it is, it's not that bad of a game. Only very repetitive.

reviewText: Linear shooter without cover system. Hallelujah!\nStory and script are nothing special. Voice acting itself was pretty decent though. It's an art to bring such cheesy lines with any confidence.\nThe gameplay is where the fun is at though. The game plays smooth with mouse and keyboard. That's something I just don't expect anymore these days. The weapons and desctructible environment go well together. It feels strangely satisfying to pull enemies into each other with the magnet gun or drop some building with a well placed grenade. It's unlike other red faction games, but it's good in it's own right.

What made the Red Faction games so much fun was the ability to blow up anything anywhere. Whilst the destruction physics make a comeback, a lot of the time it seems as if the devs threw the destructable terrain in as more of an afterthought than anything.

The first two games offered a wide variety of ways to play and whilst some mission vital paths weren't destructible pretty much everything else was, allowing for some truly versatile gameplay.

Guerrilla was a glorious glimpse of what could have been and but for a few flaws - namely the inability to rebuild things outside of mods and a lack of a true sandbox to play with - should have been the path Volition took in the development of this game.

Sadly, they didn't and the resuly is that this sequel was lackluster and mediocre at best with little in terms of replay value and nothing worth noting in the gameplay department - the levels are sometimes almost mockingly linear, to the extent I sometimes felt I was simply along for a physics engine demonstration as opposed to the engaging gameplay of previous games.

If you're looking for a destructo-physics enabled game, don't get this. Get Guerrilla instead, install some mods and enjoy it while you can becuase GFWL is going down and I doubt it'll get patched out bar pirate group intervention.

Figures. Even when we win against Microsoft, we still lose...

I played this right after finishing Red Faction Guerilla which might have been a mistake. Comparing it to Guerilla isn't a very good idea, but in my situation I can't help it.

The graphics and weapons are much better/more interesting. The magnet gun is absolutely amazing.
The problem I had was that all the time I just wanted to play Guerilla instead. It is absolutely not a open world game where you drive around with vehicles and terrorize the EDF. It's a linear third person shooter.

If you're thinking about buying this I can only say this:
If you played Red Faction Guerilla and are looking for more, you won't find it here.
If you plan to play both, I suggest you play this first because in a direct comparison it will probably look a better to you. The story plays such a long time after Guerilla that it doesn't really matter.
If you like linear, good shooters with very interesting mechanics like destruction, the magnet gun and repair spray/blasts which results in dynamic cover and physics based combat you will absolutely be happy with this game.
